1          Abstract

 

txObject Application Tool Kit (ATK) is a package of powerful C++ libraries that helps decrease project development time and increase software reliability. txObject ATK provides both embedded and application level projects a five-layer framework. Each layer offers a unified set of tools that allows developers to focus their development efforts.

txObject ATK’s five-layer framework contains the following: Object Library, IO & Timers, Threads, Inter-Process Communication, and Distributed Object Communication. All libraries are currently supported on Windows(98/NT/2000), Linux, and most variants of the Unix operating systems. Excelon Corp. ObjectStore Database support is also featured for those platforms the ObjectStore application runs on [ObjectStore Support 2.8].

 

A correlation can be made between txObject ATK and Sun Microsystems Inc. Java Language. txObject ATK has many of the advantages Java has, but without some of the performance issues commonly associated with the Java Language. Java’s initial advantages are its platform independent built-in and publicly available support libraries. Due to the basic nature of Java, its libraries have a common object-oriented feel and data flow model. txObject ATK has accomplished a similar Java-like environment for C++.

 

Another correlation can be made between txObject ATK and the CORBA Standards.  As demand increases for applications to run in distributed environments and on multiple platforms, projects have had a new added complexity to their traditional development cycle. txObject ATK greatly decreases such complexity in a similar way CORBA does but with two fundamental differences. The first distinction is that txObject ATK is a tightly coupled peer-to-peer distributed system, where CORBA is a loosely coupled client-server model. The second division is that txObject ATK distributed objects are state and transaction consistent. CORBA provides distributed object interfaces without state [Introduction 6.1].

 

txObject ATK is ideal for developing embedded applications. It has been optimized for memory and CPU constrained systems. The entire software package is comprised of 5,000 lines of class declaration code and 10,000 lines of implementation code. Further reading shall account for the size of each layer.

 

This tutorial introduces the reader informally to the basic concepts and features of the txObject ATK libraries and system. It just scratches the surface of how to use txObject ATK and what it can do. The tutorial is designed to wet your appetite. For further information see txObject ATK Application Programming Interface documentation for all class and macro definitions.

 

Each layer of the txObject ATK is a foundation for every successive layer.  In order for a particular layer to operate, it requires the layers below it but not the ones above.  Since layer 1 is the base for all other layers, close attention should be paid. Each component in layer 1 will be used intimately throughout layers 2-5.

2          Layer 1 – Object Library

2.1       Introduction

 

The following sections describe the standard types that come with txObject ATK. These are the numeric, character, sequence, and user defined types.

 

All types support some common operations; in particular, they can be compared, collected, checked for type, and converted to/from a binary stream format.

 

Two other useful features are txObject ATK’s type checking and type serialization functionality. Both will be discussed in subsequent sections.

2.2       Base Types

 

txObject ATK supports the five major base types:

 

·        Boolean

·        Doubles

·        Floats

·        Character strings 8/16 bytes

·        (signed/unsigned) Integers 32/64 bytes

2.3       txObject Types

 

Each type is derived from class txObject. Class txObject is the base of all objects within txObject ATK and provides several useful behaviors.

 

The txObject class has several virtual methods; four of them are more commonly used throughout the txObject ATK libraries. These methods are id, equals, compare, and hash.

 

The method (id) is used to uniquely identify an object instance. Commonly, this method is tied, but not limited to, the address of an allocated txObject class. For user defined type objects, this method might be overridden to define new identity behaviors.

 

The method (equals) is used to compare two objects to one another. The default behavior compares objects on an instance basis (i.e. compare by instance). A derived class such as txObject ATK’s class txString overrides this behavior by comparing the string objects character value (i.e. compare by value).

 

The method (compare) is similar to (equals), but adds additional information of greater or less than equality. There is no default behavior for this type of compare. A derived class such as txObject ATK’s class txString overrides this behavior by comparing the string objects character value, returning 0 for equality, 1 for greater than, and –1 for less than. It is invalid to call (compare) unless this method has been defined.

 

The method (hash) in correlation with the (equals) method is used in sequence types such as tables and dictionaries [Sequence Types 2.3]. Each one of these sequence types are based on hash algorithms, thus the method (hash) returns a hash value associated with this instance of an object. Once an object’s index is determined through the hash value, if it exists, the (equals) method is called to conclude equality.

 

Users deriving from txObject commonly override both (equals) and (hash), but it is not required.

2.4       Sequence Types

 

txObject ATK supports some commonly used sequence types:

 

·        Tables

·        Dictionaries

·        Lists

·        Trees

 

Each type is derived from class txObject and contains only txObject type classes. Sequence types are based on algorithms that commonly fit application needs. Both table and dictionary types are based on hash algorithms. The list type is a sequence of nodes pointing to instances of txObject(s). And lastly, the tree type is based on a balanced tree algorithm, where the (compare) method on txObject objects determines left (1), right (-1) or equality (0). All types provide iterators for walking the sequence.

 

2.5       Run Time Type Checking

 

txObject ATK provides a Run Time Type Checking system. This system is constructed at compile time. Each txObject class has a static attribute of type txString, where the txString is representative of a class’s type. For instance, txObject ATK class txFloat has an attribute txFLoat::Type, where Type is a txString equal to the name of the class “txFloat”. txObject classes have a variety of virtual methods for accessing type information.

 

Two of these methods are (className) and (classType). Method (className) returns a const character pointer to the name of the class and method classType returns a const reference to the static txString Type attribute.

 

This system also provides methods on txObject classes that compare type and derivation equality. Below is an example of two type methods, (isClass) and (isSubClass).

 

txFloat obj(123.456);

 

if (obj.isClass(txFloat::Type))

{

     cout << “This object is of type txFloat” << endl;

}

 

if (obj.isSubClass(txObject::Type))

{

     cout << “This object : “ << obj.className();

cout << “ is a sub-type of txObject” << endl;

}

 

Above describes how to interpret built-in types and sequences, but what about user-defined types. If a user has a class Foo that is derived from class txObject, how does the type checking for this object get turned on? The answer is that there are two macros used for enabling typing.

 

·        TX_DEFINE_TYPE

·        TX_DEFINE_PARENT_TYPE

 

TX_DEFINE_TYPE is placed in the Foo class declaration and TX_DEFINE_PARENT_TYPE is placed in a source definition file (the source file is most likely the file defining the class Foo).

 

The macro TX_DEFINE_TYPE takes as its only parameter the name of the class. The macro TX_DEFINE_PARENT_TYPE takes the name of the class and the name of its derivation point (i.e. parent). Below is an example of type declaration.

 

 

Example: Header

 

class Foo : public txObject

{

     TX_DEFINE_TYPE(Foo)

 

     public:

          Foo (void);

};

 

Example: Source

 

TX_DEFINE_PARENT_TYPE(Foo,txObject)

 

Foo::Foo (void)

{

}

2.6       Generic Types

 

Due to the common problem of the Standard Template Library being incompatible on platforms that support C++, macros are use to create generic object and sequence types. There are four generic type classes with two distinct purposes:

 

·        User-define generic lists

·        User-define generic vectors

 

·        User-derived txStream(s)

·        txObject ATK generated txGObject(s)

 

o       User-define generic tables, dictionaries, and trees are not currently available

 

 

The first two types provide strongly typed lists and vectors. For instance, txObject ATK class txList is a generic list of type txObject. No other types are allowed within the sequence.  There are three macros for defining generic sequences:

 

·        TX_DECLARE_GENERIC_LIST             – list declaration

·        TX_DECLARE_GENERIC_VECTOR       – vector declaration

·        TX_DEFINE_GENERIC_VECTOR            – vector definition

 

A generic list needs only one macro to define a new list sequence. Generic vectors require both a declaration macro and a definition macro.

 

Below is an example of how to declare a generic list called FooList and a generic vector called FooVector. Each sequence contains only class Foo types.

 

Example: Header

typedef Foo* FooPtr;

 

TX_DECLARE_GENERIC_LIST(Foo,FooList)   

TX_DECLARE_GENERIC_VECTOR(FooPtr,FooVector)

 

 

Example: Source

 

TX_DEFINE_GENERIC_VECTOR(FooPtr,FooVector)

 

int main (void)

{

     FooList list;

     FooVector vector(100);

 

     Foo* foo = new Foo();

 

     list.append(foo);

     vector[25] = foo;

 

     cout << “Items in List : “ << list.entries() << endl;

     cout << “Len of Vector : “ << vector.length() << endl;

 

     list.clearAndDestroy();

 

     return 1;

}

 

txObject ATK serialization will briefly be discussed here to address the role txStream and txGObject types play as generic types. For complete definition of type serialization refer to [Type Serialization 2.7] section of this tutorial.

 

The txStream class provides the user the ability to define types with their own serialization behavior. For instance, if class Foo needs to be streamed with its associated attributes, instead of deriving from class txObject, it would derive from class txStream. The first step in creating a class of type txStream is replacing the Run Time Typing macros TX_DEFINE_TYPE and TX_DEFINE_PARENT_TYPE with two new macros. Run Time Type Checking still is provided, but declared within the new generic type macros.

 

·        TX_DECLARE_STREAM_TYPE

·        TX_DEFINE_STREAM_TYPE

·        TX_DECLARE_STREAM_OPER

 

The macro TX_DECLARE_STREAM_TYPE and TX_DEFINE_STREAM_TYPE provide class Foo with the appropriate hooks to allow for object serialization. Below is an example of how to transform class Foo into a txStream class. This example introduces the methods (storeInners) and (restoreInners), as well as, macro TX_DECLARE_STREAM_OPER. These new definitions will be discussed in detail in the type serialization section [Type Serialization 2.7].

 

Example: Header

 

class Foo : public txStream

{

     TX_DECLARE_STREAM_TYPE(Foo)

 

     private:

          int _foo_data_

 

     public:

          Foo (void);

 

          void storeInners (txOut& out) const

          {

               out << _foo_data_;

          }

 

          void restoreInners (txIn& in)

          {

               in >> _foo_data_;

          }

};

 

TX_DECLARE_STREAM_TYPE_OPER(Foo)    // discussed in 2.7

 

Example: Source

 

TX_DEFINE_STREAM_TYPE(Foo,txStream)

 

Foo::Foo (void) : _foo_data_(1)

{

}

 

The last of the generic types is class txGObject. This type can self describe any user-define txStream class without having the user-defined txStream class compiled within the application. See type serialization for complete details  [Type Serialization 2.77].

2.7       Type Serialization

 

The definition of txObject ATK Type Serialization is an octet string representation of class object data and its relationships to other class object data. For example, an instance of a txList containing a sequence of txObject instances can be represented as an octet string. Below are a few examples on how to stream a txList containing three txObject objects and then reconstruct the txList from the stream.

 

int demo_streaming_one (void)

{

     txList list;

 

     list.append(new txInt32(123));

     list.append(new txString(“str2”));

     list.append(new txDouble(1235.6789));

 

     txOut out;

 

     out << list;

 

     list.clearAndDestroy(); // delete all items in list

 

     txIn in(out);

 

     in >> list;

 

cout << “ItemsInList : “ << list.entries() << endl; // three items

 

list.clearAndDestroy();

 

// all memory has been cleaned up

 

return 1;

}

 

The example above demonstrates a few of the basic types supported by txObject ATK. All txObject ATK base types and sequence types are serializable. However, not all data in a serialized stream needs to be of type txObject. For instance, C++ data types such as floats, doubles, chars, and integers may also be serialized into a stream. Below is an example of streaming C++ data types.

 

int demo_streaming_two (void)

{

     float  out_float = 123;

     double out_double = 4.5;

     unsigned long out_integer = 6789;

     char out_char_string[100] = “Hello World”;

 

     txOut out;

 

     out << out_float;

     out << out_double;

     out << out_integer;

     out << out_char_string;

 

     float in_float;

     double in_double;

     unsigned long in_integer;

     char* in_char_string;

 

     txIn in(out);

 

     in >> in_float;        // now equal to 123

     in >> in_double;       // now equal to 4.5

     in >> in_integer;      // now equal to 6789

     in >> in_char_string;  // now equal to “Hello World”;

 

     delete in_char_string; in_char_string = 0;

 

     return 1;

}

 

So far, type serialization of C++ data types and txObject ATK base and sequence types have been discussed. The last facility for streaming data is provided by classes txStream and txGObject [Generic Types 2.6]. The purpose of class txStream is to provide hooks into user-derived classes for object data serialization. In other words, for users to add their own class types that have serialization capabilities, the user must derive them from txStream.

 

To derive a new type from txStream probably suggests that the new type has attributes to be serialized. For instance, class Foo is derived from class txStream and has an attribute of type int called _foo_data_. To encapsulate this attribute within the Foo class stream, two virtual helper methods need to be defined in class Foo. These two methods are call (storeInners) and (restoreInners).  Method (storeInners) takes txOut and method (restoreInners) takes txIn as their respective arguments.

 

An additional macro TX_DECLARE_STREAM_TYPE_OPER can be declared to allow class Foo to use the << operator to stream data out of a txIn stream. The operator allows streaming at any scope within an application. The reverse >> operator is not required due to the fact that the class txOut works on data types and not the other way around. See example in section [Generic Types 2.6] for more detail.

 

The last class type used for type serialization is class txGObject. This class has the ability to represent any user-define txStream type without having the actual txStream type compiled within the application. A detailed example will be provided when the using of distributed inter-process communication is discussed. Below is an example of class txGObject.

 

int main (void)

{

Foo foo;

     txGObject* foo_image;

 

     txOut out;

 

     out << foo;

 

     // unregister class Foo from type system.

     txFactory::unregisterType(Foo::Type);

 

     txIn in(out);

 

// factory returns txGObject(s)

// if txStream types are unknown.

in >> foo_image;

 

     cout << “class type : “;

cout << foo_image->type() << endl;

     cout << “ItemsInFoo : “;

cout << foo_image->attrs()->entries() << endl;

 

     delete foo_image; foo_image = 0;

    

     return 1;

}

2.8       ObjectStore Support

 

In most applications, persisting object information to disk is quite useful. Type serialization can be used to persist data by streaming it and saving the stream to disk. However, speed and synchronization is needed when multiple threads and/or applications can access/modify this type of persisted data. As a result, txObject ATK provides an Excelon Inc. ObjectStore interface for all of its base, generic, and sequence types.

 

There is one basic concept for persisting txObject objects through ObjectStore. txObject ATK is required to be built with the compile flag OSTORE_SUPPORT. Below is an example of allocating a persisted txUInt32 and txString and inserting it into a persisted txList.

 

int main (void)

{

     os_database* db = 0;

 

     OS_ESTABLISH_FAULT_HANDLER

 

     db = os_database::open(“txObject ATK EXAMPLE DB”,0,1);

 

     txUInt32* uint = new (db,

txUInt32::get_os_typespec()) txUInt32(1234);

 

     txString* str = new(db,

txString::get_os_typespec()) txString(“ABC”);

 

     txList* list = new(db,

txList::get_os_typespec()) txList();

 

     os_database_root* root = db->create_root(“ROOT”);

 

     root->set_value(list);

 

     list->append(uint);

     list->append(str);

 

     OS_END_FAULT_HANDLER

 

     return 1;

}

3          Layer 2 – I/O and Timers Library

3.1       Introduction

 

txObject ATK layer 2 offers deterministic I/O and timer notification and processing facilities. This layer is composed of three classes, txTimer, txExtendedTimer and txSync.

3.2       Timers

 

An instance of class txTimer is used to notify a function when a specified time expires. Instances, however, will not notify the function unless the txObject ATK timer engine is cranked. To turn the timer engine over, class txTimer provides two static methods.

 

The first method is (processExpiredTimers).  When executed, it checks for any outstanding timers in the system. If there are timers that have expired, this method will trigger each instance of txTimer(s) for notification. The second method (processAndGetMinWait) processes the timers as above, returns the time expiry. See section [I/O & Timer Processing Engine 3.3] for manual timer synchronization and section [Introduction 4.1] for automatic timer synchronization.

 

Class txTimer also provides a static method (currentTime) to query the system for the system time. This method returns the time in milli-seconds since the epoch. See section [I/O & Timer Processing Engine 3.3] for a complete example of timer registration and synchronization.

 

3.3       I/O & Timer Processing Engine

 

Often applications need notification of expiring timers as well as notifications for file descriptor state transitions. Class txSync provides static methods (registerIO) for I/O notification. This method takes a function and context to be notified on.

 

The txSync class also provides a static method IoAndTime to centralize I/O and timer notification in one logical location. If layers 1 and 2 are the only txObject ATK libraries used, this method should be the heart of a program’s main loop. txTimer(s) are under the control of txSync time sequencing. See section [Introduction 4.1] for automatic synchronization.

 

The method (IoAndTime) blocks the system until the smallest timer in the system has expired or there is I/O pending. In other words, the system is blocked until there is something to do.

 

There are no strong reasons to have a spin or polling model. Event-driven processes utilize less system resources (i.e. memory/CPU) and provide more deterministic behavior. Below is an example of io and timer registration and processing.

 

// see the main function before analyzing these three

// demo functions. this example kicks

// off timers and prints to the screen. on each print,

// the screen output file descriptor

// notifies the system that I/O was written.

 

unsigned long id = 0;

 

void fd_func (void*, int, unsigned long)

{

        cout << "write to screen" << endl;

 

        txSync::unregisterIO(id);

 

        id = 0;

}

 

txTimerEnum::RETURN_STATUS timer1 (void* x)

{

        cout << "Call Timer of 1000 (ms)" << endl;

 

        if (!id)

        {

                id = txSync::registerIO(fd_func,

 0, 0, txSync::IOWrite);

        }

 

        return txTimerEnum::CONTINUE;

}

 

int main (void)

{

        int fd = 0; // file descriptor for screen output;

 

        txTimer timer(timer1, 0, 1000);

 

        id = txSync::registerIO(fd_func,

0, fd, txSync::IOWrite);

 

        for (int i = 0; i < 500; i++)

        {

txSync::IoAndTime(

txTimer::processAndGetMinWait());

 

                cout << "." << flush;

        }

 

        return 1;

}

4          Layer 3 – Thread Library

4.1       Introduction

 

txObject ATK thread library is the cornerstone for layers 4 and 5. Each component is designed for fair and reliable thread scheduling, as well as, for inter-operable consistency with other threading packages and operating systems. txObject ATK I/O & timer library in collaboration with layer 3 provides as complete a suite of features as any project needs to develop threaded applications.

 

One of the more powerful features txObject ATK system provides is its platform independent threading library. txObject ATK threads offer identical behavior on all platforms.

 

Without continual testing on multiple platforms, projects will inevitably endure headaches when the time arises to port the project. One common issue in any code port is flow control behaviors within the core. txObject ATK carefully planned its thread library to eliminate such problems. The primary reason txObject ATK threads can do this, is that its threads are not scheduled by the operating system. txObject ATK controls threads within a txObject ATK application. Such applications are not directly under the rules of the operating systems kernel, but are controlled by txObject ATK prioritized non-preemptive threading model.

 

I/O and timer synchronization is provided automatically when the thread library is linked into an application; manual synchronization is not required or allowed [I/O & Timer Processing Engine 3.3].

 

First impressions might conclude that if txObject ATK defines and schedules its own threads, they would be slower than native threads. This assumption however is not correct. In fact txObject ATK’s threading library meets or exceeds the performance of native threads. A detailed description of the thread internals would exceed the scope of this tutorial. One should run test comparisons to justify these statements.

 

txObject ATK does provide a native thread abstraction for all platforms it supports. The abstraction has the same look and feel as its own threads, but provides a preemptive thread environment (see txObject ATK Native Thread Example).

4.2       Threads

 

txObject ATK class txThread provides five static methods, one for starting and four for scheduling threads. To start a thread, the method (start) is used. This method takes a function, context, name, priority, and stack size for arguments. All but the function can be defaulted. Thread priorities range from 0 to 255, where threads 0-1 are reserved for system threads. Priority 255 is the highest priority thread in the system, but it is recommended to co-locate thread priorities close together for better performance. Allocating priorities close together (i.e. 2,3,4 etc.) will produce better performance.

 

Since txObject ATK threads are non-preemptive, the user is required to preempt them. In other words, users must allow the txObject ATK thread scheduler to run. This is accomplished through the method (yield). There are four signatures for the method (yield), one for each type of preemption. Below is an example of how to write a simple threaded application. See section [Events 4.3] for more details on txObject ATK events.

 

txObject ATK Thread Example:

 

int G_EXIT_FLAG = 0;

txEvent G_EXIT_EVENT(“EXIT”);

txEvent G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME(“DEMO EVENT”);

 

void demo_yield (void* context)

{

      while (!G_EXIT_FLAG)

      {

            txThread::yield(); // this spins CPU 100%

      }

}

 

void demo_yield_with_time (void* context)

{

      for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)

      {

            printf(“yield for 1 second : %s\n”, txThread::name());

 

            txThread::yield(1000); // yield for 1000 (ms)

      }

 

      G_EXIT_FLAG = 1;

      G_EXIT_EVENT.trigger();

}

 

void demo_yield_with_event_and_time (void* context)

{

      while (!G_EXIT_FLAG)

      {

      if (txThread::yield(

G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME,500) == 1)

            {

                  printf(“½ second timer expired\n”);

            }

            else // yield returned 0

            {

                  printf(“event triggered\n”);

            }

      }

}

 

int main (void)

{

      txThread::start(demo_yield);

      txThread::start(demo_yield_with_time);

      txThread::start(demo_yield_with_event_and_time

      txThread::yield(G_EXIT_EVENT);

 

      G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME.trigger();

     

      return 1;

}

 

txObject ATK Native Thread Example:

 

int G_EXIT_FLAG = 0;

txNativeEvent G_EXIT_EVENT(“EXIT”);

txNativeEvent G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME(“DEMO EVENT”);

 

txNativeLock  G_LOCK(“LOCK printf to protect against preemption”);

 

void demo_yield (void* context)

{

      while (!G_EXIT_FLAG)

      {

            txNativeThread::yield(); // this spins CPU 100%

      }

}

 

void demo_yield_with_time (void* context)

{

      for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)

      {

            G_LOCK.acquire();

            printf(“yield for 1 second : %s\n”, txNativeThread::name());

            G_LOCK.release();

 

            txNativeThread::yield(1000); // yield for 1000 (ms)

      }

 

      G_EXIT_FLAG = 1;

      G_EXIT_EVENT.trigger();

}

 

void demo_yield_with_event_and_time (void* context)

{

      while (!G_EXIT_FLAG)

      {

      if (txNativeThread::yield(

G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME, 500) == 1)

            {

            G_LOCK.acquire();

                  printf(“½ second timer expired\n”);

                  G_LOCK.release();

            }

            else // yield returned 0

            {

                  G_LOCK.acquire();

                  printf(“event triggered\n”);

                  G_LOCK.release();

            }

      }

}

 

int main (void)

{

      txNativeThread::start(demo_yield);

      txNativeThread::start(demo_yield_with_time);

      txNativeThread::start(demo_yield_with_event_and_time);

 

      txNativeThread::yield(G_EXIT_EVENT);

 

      G_DEMO_YIELD_WITH_EVENT_AND_TIME.trigger();

     

      return 1;

}

4.3       Events

 

An instance of class txEvent can be used in combination with txObject ATK threads, as an additional facet to the deterministic behavior of this non-preemptive thread library. Events can be used to block a thread execution until a particular transaction has occurred. Events are used in concert with the thread yield facilities [Threads 4.2].  To unblock a thread when it is being blocked by a particular event, the method (trigger) is used.

4.4       Locks

 

Often a thread needs to block a particular code segment from other threads until it has completed work on this segment. An instance of class txLock provides such mutex facilities. To lock a code segment, the method (acquire) is used at the beginning of the code segment and the method (release) is used at the end of the code segment. Method (release) notifies any pending threads waiting on the lock acquire.

 

void demo_locking_code_segments (int count)

{

      static txLock lock(“lock”);

 

      lock.acquire();

 

      for (int i = 0; i < count; i++)

      {

            call_function_that_preempts();

      }

 

      lock.release();

}

4.5       Thread Management

 

txObject ATK provides the ability to centralize and reuse txObject ATK threads. Class txThreadManager allows an application to constrain the amount of threads a process can create, as well as, reuse threads for multiple requests. Constraining thread creation in conjunction with thread reuse enables applications to throttle themselves and protect against request storms and system memory exhaustion.

5          Layer 4 – Inter-Process Communication Library

5.1       Introduction

 

txObject ATK layer 4 provides client-server and server-server inter-process communication. Internally, each component is multi-threaded.  However, from the standpoint of the programming interface, each component is single-threaded.

 

Since process communication is extremely platform specific, class txSocket is specifically written for the three major platforms: Windows (98/NT/2000), Linux, and Unix operating systems and provides a platform independent socket abstraction. See section [Using txObject  (ATK) 7.1] for more details on source file location.

 

Within this layer there are three sub-layers. First is the socket layer where the rubber meets the road. Then there is the server layer where servers manage sockets. Finally there is the server management layer that manages servers. One’s application design will determine which sub-layer to use.

5.2       Sockets

 

Socket communication has traditionally had similar interpretations within and across languages. txObject ATK class txSocket is not much different. There are, however, some features that have been added to make inter-process communication and protocol design a bit easier than traditional implementations.

 

TCP sockets as designed are stream based. txSocket enables message based communication over TCP sockets. Most TCP socket interfaces do not packetize messages to be sent and received. txObject ATK eliminates the need for developing packetizing subsystems by providing its own built-in packetizing classes txAbsPacker and txRawPacker. Class txSocket takes as one of its constructors an instance of a packer class. Users may derive from txAbsPacker and define their own packetize logic as well. The default socket behavior packetizes messages by length as they are sent and received.

 

Since messages over TCP are messaged based, class txSocket has the ability to provide a different look to its TCP receive method. The receive method (recv) will not unblock until a complete message can be reconstructed from a TCP bit stream. In other words, if a character string “Hello World” is sent to a socket waiting on (recv), the method will not unblock until the complete “Hello World” character string is received. Method (recv) takes as it parameters a reference to the class txNetworkMsgs and an integer representing the number of messages to be received before unblocking. By default the method (recv) returns as many messages as it can reconstruct. For more details on class txNetworkMsgs see section [Messaging 5.3].

 

Class txSocket provides notification when a connection has been established for a server socket and when a connection has been broken for client and server sockets. When connections are broken, sockets automatically close and cleanup.

 

Class txSocket handles both TCP and UDP communication and has many more features than described in this tutorial. See txObject ATK Application Programming Interface for complete class definition. Below is an example of a client and server application.

 

Server Example:

 

txEvent G_EXIT_EVENT(“EXIT”);

 

void lost (void*, txSocket* client)

{

      cout << “client down : “ << client->netaddr();

cout << “@” << client->port() << endl;

}

 

void estab (void*, txSocket* client)

{

      client->registerContactLost(lost, 0)

 

      cout << “client up : “ << client->netaddr();

cout << “@” << client->port() << endl;

 

client->send(“HELLO CLIENT”, 13);

 

// allow data to be sent before exiting program.

txThread::yield();

 

G_EXIT_EVENT.trigger();

}

 

int main (void)

{

txSocket server(SOCK_STREAM);  // using TCP and default packer.

 

server.registerContactEstablished(estab, 0);

server.bind(5555);              // bind to local host

server.listen(1);

 

txThread::yield(G_EXIT_EVENT);

 

return 1;

}

 

 

Client Example:

 

void lost (void*, txSocket* server)

{

      cout << “server down : “ << server->netaddr();

cout << “@” << server->port() << endl;

}

 

void estab (void*, txSocket* server)

{

      cout << “server up : “ << server->netaddr();

cout << “@” << server->port() << endl;

}

 

int main (void)

{

txNetworkMsg* m;

txNetworkMsgs msgs;

unsigned long netaddr = txSocket::generateLocalNetAddr(txSocket::OUT_OF_BAND);

 

txSocket client(SOCK_STREAM);   // using TCP and default packer.

 

client.registerContactEstablished(estab, 0);

client.registerContactLost(lost, 0);

client.connect(netaddr, 5555);  // connect to server at 5555

 

client.recv(msgs);

 

while (m = msgs.get())

{

      cout << “MESSAGE : “ << m->data() << endl;

      cout << “MESSAGE LENGTH : “ << m->length() << endl;

 

      delete m; m = 0;

}

 

return 1;

}

5.3       Messaging

 

txObject ATK messaging classes txNetworkMsg and txNetworkMsgs are used in both socket and server sub-layers. These classes provide two distinct behaviors; buffer reuse and message origination. Buffer reuse is self-explanatory, however there is one note to be made. txObject ATK object serialization and inter-process communication share and reuse stream buffers for optimal object message passing [Type Serialization 2.7].

 

Within the txObject ATK server-server model of communication, it is necessary to identify where each message originated. As a result, each txNetworkMsg instance has an instance of class txAbsPeer representing the message origin. See section [Process Identities 5.4] for peer definition and section [Server Communication 5.5] for a detailed messaging example.

5.4       Process Identities

 

txObject ATK process identities are logical peer identifiers that indicate server location within a network. Class txAbsPeer is the base class for all identifiers. txObject ATK exclusively supports IP server communication, and as a result, class txIpPeer is the only identifier currently derived from txAbsPeer. txObject ATK has however designed layer 4 to extend beyond IP communication for future releases.

 

Process Identities also define peer-to-peer communication security. Peer communication is open by default, but can be secured by setting an encryption key. See example in section [Server Communication 5.5] for process identity usage and security.

5.5       Server Communication

 

Server communication is the foundation of txObject ATK distributed inter-process communication. Most features in layer 4, more than meet the needs of client- server applications. Server-server communication is a distributed peer-to-peer relationship where no one process dictates another process’ behavior. Servers stand independent of one another, but together they work hand in hand as peers.

 

A Project design that incorporates the server-server model should look closely at txObject ATK fifth layer for simplifying the design [Introduction 6.1].

 

There are two server types, classes txTCPServer and txUDPServer, each with identical interfaces. Below is an example of a server application. This example can be rewritten with either type; for this example txTCPServer is used.

 

// see the function main before analyzing functions estab and lost.

// this program demonstrates the how to create peer-to-peer

// communication using class txTCPServer. the first part of the

// main is showing how to generate ip information to be used to

// create peer identifiers. once the identifiers are created,

// the program creates an instance of txTCPServer and tries

// to connect to the peers of interest. if a connection is made,

// the server sends hello messages. at the bottom of the main, the

// server waits for hello messages from its peers.

 

void estab (void* obj, txAbsPeer* peer)

{

      txTCPServer* self = (txTCPServer*) obj;

 

      // “127.0.0.1@6666” or “127.0.0.1@7777”

      cout << “up : “ << peer->getId() << endl;

 

      while (self->sendTo(“Hello Peer”, 11, *peer))

      {

            txThread::yield(2000); // send hello every 2 seconds.

      }

}

 

void lost (void*, txAbsPeer* peer)

{

      cout << “down : “ << peer->getId() << endl;

}

 

int main (void)

{

      txNetworkMsg* m;

      txNetworkMsgs msgs;

      char demo_ip [100];

      unsigned long demo_netaddr;

 

demo_netaddr = txSocket::generateLocalNetAddr(txSocket::OUT_OF_BAND);

txSocket::generateIp(demo_netaddr, demo_ip);

 

cout << “Display local ip : “ << demo_ip << endl;

 

txIpPeer self(“127.0.0.1”, 5555, txAbsPeer::TCP_SERVER);

txIpPeer peer1(“127.0.0.1”, 6666, txAbsPeer::TCP_SERVER);

txIpPeer peer2(demo_netaddr, 7777, txAbsPeer::TCP_SERVER);

 

// to secure communication between peers

// self.setEncryption(txOctetString(“MAGIC COOKIE”, 12));

// peer1.setEncryption(txOctetString(“MAGIC COOKIE”, 12));

// peer2.setEncryption(txOctetString(“MAGIC COOKIE”, 12));

 

txTCPSServer server(self);

 

server.registerContactEstablished(estab, &server);

server.registerContactLost(lost, 0);

 

server.contact(peer1);

server.contact(peer2);

 

// or instead of contact, sendTo does an auto-connect

// server.sendTo(“Hello Client”, 11, peer1);

// server.sendTo(“Hello Client”, 11, peer2);

 

      while (server.recv(msgs))

      {

            while (m = msgs.get())

            {

                  cout << “Message from : “ << m->peer->getId();

cout << endl;

                  cout << “        says : “ << m->data() << endl;

                  delete m; m = 0;

            }

      }

 

      return 1;

}

5.6       Server Management

 

Server management forwards communication request to managed server objects. Class txIPCServer manages txTCPServer and txUDPServer class types by centralizing TCP and UDP communication. Class txIPCServer has an identical interface to that of txTCPServer and txUDPServer. The example in section [Server Communication 5.5] can be rewritten to use class txIPCServer.

 

A Project design that incorporates the server-server model should look closely at txObject ATK fifth layer for simplifying the design [Introduction 6.1].

6          Layer 5 – Distributed Object Framework

6.1       Introduction

 

The fifth layer’s objective is to provide projects with an easy to use distributed object-oriented infrastructure. It is analogous to projects using shared memory between processes local to one computer or over an IP network. By creating txObject ATK distributed objects, users can manipulate and organize all components of a distributed object locally or remotely. Everything from changing an attribute to invoking methods can be preformed on objects both locally and remotely that are part of a shared memory group.

 

The next section will explain txObject ATK’s view on solving the problems of multiple processes managing and manipulating distributed objects.

6.2       Distributed Processing

 

txObject ATK distributed infrastructure is divided into three major components: distributed objects, distributed memory spaces, and distributed managers. A process can contain one or more managers, each manager can manage one or more memory spaces, and each memory space can contain one or more objects.

 

The three divisions are designed to distinguish the major components of an application and help projects retrofit existing applications and/or develop new applications for distributed purposes.

 

The three steps for designing a distributed application is to understanding how your information is to be identified, organized and notified.

 

  • Step one - identify what information needs to be replicated.
  • Step two - organize how this information should be stored.
  • Step three - recognize how processes should be notified of changes to this information.

 

The one clear distinction between shared memory and txObject ATK’s distributed architecture is txObject ATK ability’s to notify applications of state changes. State can be represented as an attribute or as a process’s interest in particular distributed components.

6.3       Distributed Objects

 

To create a distributed object one needs to derive from class txDObject and register which attributes and methods one wishes to have distributed. All attributes must be of type txObject* and serializable and all methods must be static.

 

The following example demonstrates how to created a distributed object. It shows how to declare and define a user-defined txDObject. This example only exhibits a few methods one can use. For complete functional details see txObject ATK Application Programming Interface.

 

Header Example:

 

class Foo : public txDObject

{

      TX_DECLARE_DOBJECT(Foo)

 

      private:

          //

          // distributed attribute

          //

          txUInt32* _foo_data_;

 

          //

          // two distributed methods

          //

          static txObject* _getFooDate_ (

Foo* self, txIn&, const txAbsPeer&);

          static txObject* _invokeSetOnFooData_ (

Foo* self, txIn&, const txAbsPeer&);

 

      public:

            Foo (void)

{

_foo_data_ = new txUInt32(0);

}

 

            ~Foo (void)

            {

                  delete _foo_data_; _foo_data_ = 0;

            }

 

            txUInt32* getFooData (void)

            {

                  return _getFooData_(this);

}

 

void changeFooDataLocally (int data)

{

_foo_data_->value(data);

}

 

            void invokeSetFooData (int data, const txIpPeer& peer)

            {

                  txUInt32 tmp(data);

 

                  //

                  // show how to execute a distributed method

// on a particular peer.

                  //

                  invokeStaticOneWayMethod(

“_invokeSetFooData_”, &tmp, peer);

            }

 

            virtual void createNotify (void)

            {

                  //

                  // demonstrates the ability to be notify on create

                  //

                  cout << “be notified when Foo is created locally”

cout << “ or remotely” << endl;

            }

 

            virtual void destroyNofity (void)

            {

                  //

                  // demonstrates the ability to be notified on destroy

                  //

                  cout << “be notified when Foo is destroyed locally”

cout << “ or remotely” << endl;

 

            }

 

            virtual void attrWriteNotify (const char*, const txObject*,

const txObject*)

            {

                  //

                  // demonstrates the ability to be notified when a

// attribute changes. first argument is the attribute

// name, second argument is the old attribute value,

// and the third argument is the new attribute value.

                  //

                  cout << “be notified when an attribute has changed”;

cout << endl;

            }

 

            virtual void contactEstablishedNotify (

const txAbsPeer& peer)

            {

                  //

                  // demonstrates the ability to be notified when peers

// joining a particular memory spaces manager

                  //

                  cout << “new peer has become a member of this”

cout << “ object’s memory space” << endl;

            }

};

 

Source Example:

 

TX_DEFINE_DOBJECT(Foo,txDObject)

 

void Foo::restoreComplete (void)

{

      //

      // required to be defined - useful for advance users needing to

// initialize. distributed attributes after txObject ATK has

// create and de-serialized this object.

      //

}

 

// the place to register attributes and methods

void Foo::registerInners (void) const

{

      //

      // register the attribute _foo_data_ to be distributed.

      //

registerAttribute("_foo_data_", &_foo_data_);

 

      //

      // register a request/response distributed method

      //

registerTwoWayMethod(

"_getFooData_", (TX_METHOD_PTR) Foo::_getFooData_);

 

//

// register a request distributed method – non-blocking

//

registerStaticOneWayMethod(

“_setFooData_”, (TX_METHOD_PTR) Foo::_setFooData_);

}

 

void Foo::_getFooData_ (Foo* self)

{

txObject* retval = 0;

 

      //

      // check to see if this distributed object is owned by

// this processs.

      //

if (self->ownedLocally())

{

retval = new txUInt32(self->__foo_data_->value());

}

//

// if ownership is somewhere else, forward the executed to

// the owning process.

//

else

{

retval = self->invokeTwoWayMethod("_getFooData_");

}

 

return retval;

}

 

void Foo::_setFooData_ (Foo* self, txIn& in, const txAbsPeer& peer)

{

      cout << “request came from : “ << peer.getId() << endl;

 

      //

      // destream arguments. it is advised to check argument

// types before proceeding.

      //

      txUInt32 foo_data; in >> foo_data;

 

      //

      // check to see if this distributed object is owned by this

// processs.

      //

      if (self->ownedLocally())

      {

            self->_foo_data_->value(foo_data.value());

 

            //

            // update this attribute change to all interested processes

// and commit.

            //

            self->attrWrite("_foo_data_", self->_foo_data_);

            self->commit();

      }

//

// if ownership is somewhere else, forward the execution to the

// owning process.

//

      else

      {

            self->invokeStaticOneWayMethod("_setFooData_", &foo_data);

      }

}

 

6.4       Distributed Memory Spaces

 

Creating distributed spaces is an indirect operation. Distributed memory spaces are created when a distributed object is registered.  Distributed objects in a distributed space may not refer to other objects in other spaces, thus great care should be put into organizing how many spaces one wishes to create and which objects these spaces contain.  In essence, spaces are logical organization of objects. They give objects a home with an address.

 

The following example demonstrates how to allocate and register a distributed object in a distributed space. (Note: once an object has been registered it is now a smart pointer and needs to be de-referenced to be accessed).

 

int allocateAndRegister (const txIpPeer& localAddress)

{

      //

      // allocate an instance of Foo and register it as an instance in

// a space.

      //

      Foo* foo_instance = new Foo();

 

      TX_REGISTER_DOBJECT(

Foo, foo_instance, “FooSpace”, &localAddress);

 

      //

      // allocate an instance of Foo and register it as a well known

// instance in a space. if “THE_FOO” has already been created,

// this macro deletes the previously allocated foo_global and

// replaces it with the global Foo instance.

      //

      Foo* foo_global = new Foo();

 

      TX_REGISTER_NAMED_DOBJECT_IN_SPACE(

Foo, foo_global, “FOO”, “FooSpace”, &localAddress);

 

      txUInt32* attr = (*foo_global)->getFooData();

 

      if (attr->value() == 0)

      {

      cout << “attribute has not yet been set to anything”;

cout << endl;

}

 

delete attr; attr = 0;

}

6.5       Distributed Object Management

 

Distributed managers are the entry point into txObject ATK’s distributed subsystem. A manager is a member of a group of managers supervising memory spaces. Each manager is identified by its peer address, which corresponds to an IP and Port Number.

 

To become a member of a manager group, one can contact any one of the managers that are part of the existing group. Once becoming a group member, one can join memory spaces. When a process joins a memory space it gets all the associated distributed objects within that space. The new manager then can proceed adding new distributed objects or changing existing ones.

 

Below is an example of how to create a distributed manager, access a distributed space, and access a globally named distributed object.

 

void estab (txDObjMgr* mgr, void* obj)

{

txIpPeer* peer = (txIpPeer*) obj;

cout << "-----------> CONTACT ESTABLISHED : ";

cout << peer->getId() << endl;

}

 

void lost (txDObjMgr* mgr, void* obj)

{

txIpPeer* peer = (txIpPeer*) obj;

cout << "-----------> CONTACT LOST : ";

cout << peer->getId() << endl;

}

 

void error (txDObjMgr* mgr, void* obj)

{

txDObjError* error = (txDObjError*) obj;

cout << "-----------> T ERROR - Code : ";

cout << error->code() << endl;

delete error; error = 0;

}

 

int startAndStop_txObject_Distributed_SubSystem (void)

{

txIpPeer localAddress(“127.0.0.1”, 2222, txAbsPeer::TCP);

 

txDObjMgr* mgr = new txDObjMgr(

localAddress, txPeerList(), txList(), estab, lost, error);

 

txIpPeer peerAddress(“127.0.0.1”, 3333, txAbsPeer::TCP);

 

mgr->addPeer(peerAddress);

 

cout << “All known peers : “;

cout << mgr->allKnownPeers()->entries() << endl;

 

mgr->joinSpace(“FooSpace”);

 

const txDObjSpace* space = mgr->accessSpace(“FooSpace”);

 

// object addresses look like this, get well known

char oid[] = “FooSpace/FOO”;

 

Foo* foo_global = (Foo*) space->accessObject(oid);

 

      delete mgr; mgr = 0;

}

7          Summary

7.1       Using txObject  (ATK)
